The patch doesn't address the underlying problem, which is that state is leaking between some specs. Need to figure out where/why/how that's happening.

Man I cannot figure this one out. The around hook in spec helper _should_ be clearing out all metadata before each example run. Cannot figure out why its not. Anyway, I have another not as dirty hack as the last one. This is in the sandbox method:

```
new_config = RSpec::Core::Configuration.new

new_config.include_or_extend_modules.clear
new_config.include RSpec::Matchers
new_config.extend RSpec::Matchers::DSL

new_world  = RSpec::Core::World.new(new_config)
```

It's not clearing it out because of the way `add_setting` handles defaults. They are global, which is why `new_config.include_or_extend_modules.clear` works. This is only a problem in this spec suite (any end-user suite would only have one `Configuration` instance anyhow), so this is not a big problem, but it would be cleaner if defaults were copied into `settings` as needed, but not referenced directly.
Got it. I'll see what I can do.

I understand how it all works, but I don't understand what you mean by "it would be cleaner if defaults were copied into settings as needed, but not referenced directly"

As needed? `include_or_extend_modules` needs to keep its state for the entire suite run to do its intended functionality.

I think its current design suits its purpose very well. Changing the implementation just to support the RSpec spec suite is "meh".

Anyway, how do you want to handle this so the pending example can be removed?

Thanks.

The `Configuration` object that you get from `RSpec.configuration` is a global instance. It _is_ the global state, so it need not maintain global state internally.  There is no programmatic benefit for defaults to be stored at the class level in `Configuration`, yet they are, and the fact that they are reduces testability by bleeding global state across examples that use other instances of `Configuration`.

"I think its current design suits its purpose very well. Changing the implementation just to support the RSpec spec suite is "meh"."

This is a debate that has been present in the TDD community for a decade by now. Testability is a value, just like any other in software. To the extent that code introduces testability problems, it fails to serve its purpose. That doesn't mean you should do absurd shit to make code testable, or compromise an object's ability to perform its runtime responsibilities to the application it lives in. It's all about balance and trade-offs. But if two designs serve the needs of the app equally well, and one is more testable than the other, the more testable design wins.

What I'd like to do in this case, is this: when assigning default values to a setting (which should happen the first time a setting is requested and it hasn't yet been set), if the value is a data structure like an Array or a Hash, a copy should be made and assigned to the setting for that instance. This way other instances won't be accessing the same Array or Hash object as the global one. Make sense?
Is this all possible _without_ making an API change?

Sure. The API is an instance level API. 
RSpec.configure do |c|
  c.add_setting :foo
end

What I'm confused about is this:

In rspec-rails you have:

```
RSpec.configure do |c|
  c.include RSpec::Rails::FixtureSupport
end
```

That is doing the same thing as (in configuration_spec):

```
it "includes each one before deciding whether to include the next" do
  mod1 = Module.new do
    def self.included(host)
      host.metadata[:foo] = :bar
    end
  end
  config.include(mod1)
```

So _how_ do you determine what is a "default value"?

Thanks.
http://github.com/rspec/rspec-core/blob/master/features/configuration/custom_settings.feature

That API is being used internally to build up settings, and is exposed externally for extension libraries like rspec-rails to add its own settings.

This has no bearing on `config.include` or `config.extend`, both of which delegate to an array that is the default value of the setting.

In configuration_spec.rb, each "config" subject (in an example group) _must_ have this array for `include_or_extend_modules`:

```
[[:include, RSpec::Matchers, {}], [:extend, RSpec::Matchers::DSL, {}]]
```

Obviously, the problem is some of these "config" subjects are keeping much more than that in their array (injected from previous example groups).

So my question is: What separates `c.include RSpec::Rails::FixtureSupport` from `config.include(MyModule)`? To me, they are doing the exact same thing. How do you determine that `c.include RSpec::Rails::FixtureSupport` _should_ be included in a new instance of Configuration? How do you determine what is the default state?

I must be completely missing something.
I think this might be something where I'm just going to have to see it.

That would be a nice API to expose to extension lib authors. WDYT?
